intro: Aphanomyrtus octandra, commonly known as the mountain gum or black gum, is a species of flowering plant in the myrtle family, Myrtaceae. It is native to eastern Australia, where it typically grows in dry, rocky soils and open forests. The plant is characterized by its narrow, lance-shaped leaves and small, white or pale pink flowers that appear in clusters. Its fruits are woody capsules that release seeds when mature, contributing to its propagation in suitable habitats. Aphanomyrtus octandra is often used in horticulture for its ornamental value and ability to thrive in harsh environmental conditions.
